s: Our household did not often feast on pancakes or waffles, so syrup was not of real importance to us, however my Dad liked the thick consistency of KING syrup.; Mom preferring Aunt Jemima brand. My hubby grew up on the MRS. BUTTERWORTH (usually blended with peanut butter and slathered on "whatever").

t: Mrs. Butterworth's - Wikipedia
s: March 17, 2025 - Mrs. Butterworth's is an American brand of table syrups and pancake mixes owned by Conagra Brands. The syrups come in distinctive bottles shaped as the character "Mrs. Butterworth", represented in the form of a "matronly" woman. The syrup was introduced in 1961.

t: Conagra Brands reviewing Mrs. Butterworth's brand after Aunt Jemima, Uncle Ben's announcements
s: June 19, 2020 - Conagra Brands has “begun a complete brand and packaging review on Mrs. Butterworth's.” Aunt Jemima and Uncle Ben's announced similar moves Wednesday.

t: Mrs. Butterworth's, Cream of Wheat join Aunt Jemima, Uncle Ben's in changing brand amid racial protests - Good Morning America
s: Conagra Brands, the parent company of Mrs. Butterworth's, announced Wednesday the brand has begun a "complete brand and packaging review" of its syrup products, which critics say feature offensive phrases and imagery.

t: What Happened With the Mrs. Butterworth's Bottle Change? - DIELINE
s: December 4, 2024 - In July 2020, Conagra also announced it would conduct a brand review for Mrs. Butterworth’s, acknowledging that consumers could see the packaging, particularly its signature syrup bottle silhouette, as racist.

t: Company behind Mrs. Butterworth’s now doing ‘complete brand and packaging review’ | The Hill
s: June 18, 2020 - Conagra Brands Inc. announced this week that it is launching a “complete brand and packaging review” on its Mrs. Butterworth’s products, while also acknowledging it can understand how its “packaging may be interpreted in a way” that is not consistent with its values.
